2nd year: Sedimentological investigation of the Ecca Group exposed in Laingsburg, Western Cape.
projects.description:
This study involved a comprehensive and detailed lithological, sedimentological and structural investigation of the lower Ecca Group in Laingsburg, Western Cape. The Ecca group hosts a ~ 245 million year old organic-rich black shale, which has recently been the focus of interest of petroleum companies worldwide. The shale was deposited under anoxic conditions in a setting which formed as a consequence of retro-arc foreland basin development related to the Cape Fold Belt. This sedimentary/tectonic environment provided the perfect conditions for deeply buried black shales to reach maturity levels for development in the gas window.
The investigated site contained outcrops of the Dwyka, the Ecca and the lower Beaufort Groups. The outcrops were mapped extensively and the data was used in conjuction with GPS coordinates  and stratigraphic profiles to produce a detailed geological map of the area. North-South cross sections were drawn to give  indication of bed thickness and formation depth.
This project formed part of the ongoing investigation of the Ecca Groups black shale as potential gas targets.
